results.abstract: NASA releases 13-minute video retrieved from wreckage near Palestine, Tex, showing Columbia astronauts doing routine tasks, hamming it up for camera and marveling at light show from jet of superheated gases that some investigators believe somehow entered body of vehicle and brought it down; second unrelated and as yet unreleased video, prepared by board investigating accident, may shed more light on what happened; tape, composite of hundreds of still and video images from many sources, reportedly shows Columbia shedding debris as it starts across continental US; photo (M)

headline.main: Video Shows Astronauts Before Shuttle Disintegrated

results.snippet: A video released today by NASA shows the Columbia astronauts marveling at the light show from superheated gases during re-entry -- the plasma that may have contributed to the destruction of the shuttle minutes later.    The 13 minutes of video,...
results.lead_paragraph: A video released today by NASA shows the Columbia astronauts marveling at the light show from superheated gases during re-entry -- the plasma that may have contributed to the destruction of the shuttle minutes later. The 13 minutes of video, retrieved from tape discovered amid the wreckage near Palestine, Tex., on Feb. 6, appears at first viewing to be like any normal mission. The astronauts go about the business of preparing for re-entry, pulling on gloves and stowing gear, bantering with one another and hamming it up for the camera.

results.abstract: New York Mets honor fallen crew of Columbia Space Shuttle by inviting 1,000 NASA employees to exhibition game (S)

headline.main: Mets Honor Columbia Crew And NASA Staff

results.snippet: Mark Polansky wore a Mets T-shirt underneath his NASA jumpsuit, to match his blue Mets cap. Mike Massimino, a fellow astronaut, joined Polansky behind home plate, watching batting practice, before Tom Seaver came up for a handshake.    ''Holy cow,''...
results.lead_paragraph: Mark Polansky wore a Mets T-shirt underneath his NASA jumpsuit, to match his blue Mets cap. Mike Massimino, a fellow astronaut, joined Polansky behind home plate, watching batting practice, before Tom Seaver came up for a handshake. ''Holy cow,'' Massimino said when introduced to Seaver. ''My heroes growing up were my dad, Tom Seaver and Neil Armstrong.''

results.abstract: Article on NASA's efforts to overcome safety problems in three remaining space shuttles, task made urgent by needs of International Space Station and crew in orbit 240 miles above Earth; Russia will ferry astronauts, but without carrying power of American shuttles station will have to limp along with smaller crews and poor prospects for expansion; shuttle repair investigations are guided by leading theory of Columbia calamity, that piece of insulation or other flying debris damaged protective tiles on liftoff, dooming spacecraft; proposals for redesigning external fuel tank that was source of debris explained; diagrams (M)

headline.kicker: LOSS OF THE SHUTTLE: THE FUTURE
headline.main: NASA Studies How to Make Three Remaining Shuttles Safe to Fly Again

results.snippet: Though investigators have yet to agree on why the space shuttle Columbia disintegrated over Texas last month, NASA is already studying how to overcome safety problems in the nation's fleet of three remaining shuttles -- a task given special urgency,...

byline.original: This article was reported by William J. Broad, Matthew L. Wald and Edward Wong and written by Mr. Broad

results.lead_paragraph: Though investigators have yet to agree on why the space shuttle Columbia disintegrated over Texas last month, NASA is already studying how to overcome safety problems in the nation's fleet of three remaining shuttles -- a task given special urgency, officials say, by the needs of the International Space Station and its crew, in orbit 240 miles above Earth. Atlantis was to have blasted off from Cape Canaveral last Saturday with a fresh crew and supplies, relieving the three astronauts -- two Americans and a Russian -- who have been on the station since November. But the shuttles are grounded as investigators try to determine what caused the accident that killed seven astronauts on Feb. 1.

results.abstract: Harold W Gehman Jr, chairman of independent board investigating breakup of space shuttle Columbia, chooses three additional members: former astronaut Sally Ride, Nobel physicist Douglas D Osheroff and John Logsdon, director of Space Policy Institute of Elliott School of International Affairs at George Washington University; Sean O'Keefe, NASA administrator, is expected to approve appointments; people have complained that board lacked scientists of national prominence (M)

headline.main: Panel Leader Wants to Add Three to Inquiry Into Columbia

results.snippet: The chairman of the independent board investigating the breakup of the space shuttle Columbia announced this evening that he has chosen three additional members, including the former astronaut Sally Ride, who twice flew on the shuttle Challenger and...
results.lead_paragraph: The chairman of the independent board investigating the breakup of the space shuttle Columbia announced this evening that he has chosen three additional members, including the former astronaut Sally Ride, who twice flew on the shuttle Challenger and served on the board that investigated its loss 17 years ago. Harold W. Gehman Jr., the retired admiral who is chairman of the panel, said he also wanted to add Douglas D. Osheroff, who won the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1996, and John Logsdon, director of the Space Policy Institute of the Elliott School of International Affairs at George Washington University.

results.abstract: Robots are still human-dependent machines that can perform only specialized tasks, but researchers are working hard to change that by having them interact more with humans; not all researchers believe that all-purpose humanoid robot is realistic goal; training methods and interactions at various research sites discussed; photos (M)

headline.main: Getting to Know All About You

results.snippet: CALL it crazy, but Monica Nicolescu has taken a robot under her wing. At a robotics laboratory at the University of Southern California, she puts the two-wheeled machine through its paces, leading it through a maze of short plastic pillars to an...
results.lead_paragraph: CALL it crazy, but Monica Nicolescu has taken a robot under her wing. At a robotics laboratory at the University of Southern California, she puts the two-wheeled machine through its paces, leading it through a maze of short plastic pillars to an orange box on the floor. It follows her around the lab, observing and reproducing her every step. Through this high-tech game of monkey-see, monkey-do, Ms. Nicolescu and her colleagues train robots to perform simple jobs like picking up the box. But their goal, and that of other robotics researchers, is to build robots that will be capable of doing not only tasks they have been programmed for, but new and more complicated ones as well.

results.abstract: Article on treehouses built for adults; focuses on TreeHouse Workshop Inc of Seattle, Wash, one of handful of builders specializing in treehouse construction for adults; several houses described; photos (M)

headline.main: Out on a Limb: Treehouses for Adults

results.snippet: KIT AND KAREN SICKELS want a treehouse. They are not grade-school siblings begging their father to build them a backyard fort, nor environmental advocates plotting a yearlong stay at the top of a redwood to protest logging practices. They are just a...
results.lead_paragraph: KIT AND KAREN SICKELS want a treehouse. They are not grade-school siblings begging their father to build them a backyard fort, nor environmental advocates plotting a yearlong stay at the top of a redwood to protest logging practices. They are just a pleasant couple from Southern California -- he a 64-year-old semiretired real estate developer and she a 50-something former teacher -- who want to live part time in a tree. Two years ago, they bought 80 rocky acres several hours from their house in La Jolla. Now that they have transformed it with apple orchards, olive trees, grapevines, wild turkeys, pheasants, even 13-foot sunflowers, they need a place to stay and enjoy it. So they are planning a treehouse. A $150,000 treehouse, to be precise.

results.abstract: Scene described as team of US government and contract workers and volunteers conduct systematic search of cow pasture in Corsicana, Tex, for pieces of Columbia space shuttle; NASA researchers believe field may contain many pieces of shuttle's left wing, where signs of trouble began to appear during re-entry; more than 3,000 searchers from 43 states, led by Federal Emergency Management Agency, are conducting searches in northern and eastern Texas; photos (M)

headline.main: Hunting Shuttle Clues, Inch by Inch

results.snippet: ''Hold!'' The shout came from Ernesto Umana, an employee of the United States Forest Service, and the line of his co-workers halted its slow sweep across the grassy cow pasture. Mr. Umana had found a one-by-three-inch piece of insulating tile from...
results.lead_paragraph: ''Hold!'' The shout came from Ernesto Umana, an employee of the United States Forest Service, and the line of his co-workers halted its slow sweep across the grassy cow pasture. Mr. Umana had found a one-by-three-inch piece of insulating tile from the space shuttle Columbia sticking up from a muddy puddle. A NASA engineer, John Connolly, walked over to examine it, and judged it a keeper. ''That's a pretty good one,'' he said. One side had the black coating of the tiles designed to deflect the greatest heat.

results.abstract: Photo of Sandra Anderson, widow of space shuttle Columbia astronaut Lieutenant Col Michael Anderson, placing rose on coffin at Arlington National Ceremony; photo of NASA Admr Sean O'Keefe watching as coffin is carried to burial site
results.snippet: Photo of Sandra Anderson, widow of space shuttle Columbia astronaut Lieutenant Col Michael Anderson, placing rose on coffin at Arlington National Ceremony; photo of NASA Admr Sean O'Keefe watching as coffin is carried to burial site

results.abstract: Robert H Daugherty, NASA engineer, says his e-mail messages to colleagues warning of potentially catastrophic consequences from in-flight damage to space shuttle Columbia were hypothetical exchanges and not meant to predict accident that destroyed shuttle, telephone news conference; says his messages were given adequate consideration by space agency officials and he saw no indication they were shoved aside or not taken seriously; Daugherty and his supervisor Dr Mark Shuart speak publicly about e-mail exchanges for first time after getting permission from independent board that is investigating disaster; conference call is set up by NASA, apparently to deflect suggestions that its officials ignored explicit warnings of disaster; photo (M)

headline.main: NASA E-Mail Writer Says He Was Hypothesizing, Not Predicting Disaster

results.snippet: A NASA engineer whose e-mail messages to colleagues warned of potentially catastrophic consequences from in-flight damage to the space shuttle Columbia said yesterday that the exchanges were hypothetical and not meant to predict the accident that...
results.lead_paragraph: A NASA engineer whose e-mail messages to colleagues warned of potentially catastrophic consequences from in-flight damage to the space shuttle Columbia said yesterday that the exchanges were hypothetical and not meant to predict the accident that destroyed the shuttle. The engineer, Robert H. Daugherty of NASA's Langley Research Center in Hampton, Va., said in a telephone news conference that his messages were given adequate consideration by space agency officials and that there was no indication they were shoved aside or not taken seriously.

results.abstract: Maggie Jones article on preimplantation genetic diagnosis (PGD) to check for chromosomal abnormalities in three-day-old eggs of women like her who have had multiple miscarriages and are undergoing in vitro fertilization; notes that in her case, implantation with embryo selected as result of PGD biopsy did not succeed in making her pregnant and that she and her husband are exploring adoption; photo (L)
results.snippet: After I had four miscarriages, my body was a mystery to me. Something wasn't working, but no test, no doctor, no treatment could reveal a definitive problem. My seemingly textbook-perfect in vitro fertilization procedure -- in which I had six very...
results.lead_paragraph: After I had four miscarriages, my body was a mystery to me. Something wasn't working, but no test, no doctor, no treatment could reveal a definitive problem. My seemingly textbook-perfect in vitro fertilization procedure -- in which I had six very good embryos and my doctor transferred the three most beautiful, symmetrical and hearty-looking of the batch to my uterus -- also failed for no discernible reason. ''It's probably chromosomes,'' my doctor said, after explaining that embryos with chromosomal abnormalities aren't as likely to attach to the uterus. ''But we just can't tell.'' Which left me wondering about the three embryos that my doctor hadn't put in my womb, the ones left behind to disintegrate in the lab. Were they the healthy ones? Were they the ones that would have resulted in a baby? Recently, my doctor suggested a somewhat controversial procedure that might offer answers. Known as preimplantation genetic diagnosis, or P.G.D., the procedure is a bit like an early checkup on a baby-to-be, except it would take place before I even had a fetus. It would occur while my embryos sat in a petri dish and were a mere six to eight cells -- smaller than specks of dust.

results.abstract: Impromptu memorial springs up at main gate to Johnson Space Center in Houston honoring seven astronauts who died aboard Columbia shuttle on Feb 1; just beyond gate seven new trees are added to 33 existing trees in Astronaut Memorial Grove, one for each astronaut who has died in line of duty, from accidents or disease; photo (M)

headline.main: Seven Solemn New Arrivals At NASA's Memorial Grove

results.snippet: At the main gate to the Johnson Space Center, an instant shrine popped up after the loss of the shuttle Columbia on Feb. 1. Such ephemeral memorials have become as much a part of the public response to awful events as satellite trucks, and the...
results.lead_paragraph: At the main gate to the Johnson Space Center, an instant shrine popped up after the loss of the shuttle Columbia on Feb. 1. Such ephemeral memorials have become as much a part of the public response to awful events as satellite trucks, and the assemblages of flowers, poems and balloons fade in less time than it takes for the nation's attention to drift to the next compelling event. But just beyond the gate, which still bears banners and messages, there is something less known and more permanent: a stand of trees called the Astronaut Memorial Grove. One tree has been planted in honor of each astronaut who has died, whether in the line of duty or from accidents or disease. Until Feb. 1, the grove had 33 trees. George W. S. Abbey, who began the grove in 1996 when he was director of the center, said when asked about the memorial: ''Now, unfortunately, we have to plant seven more. All at once.''

results.abstract: NASA releases documents showing that agency, in preparing for shuttle mission immediately before fatal Columbia flight, flagged as a major concern a loss of foam on fuel tanks where investigators now theorize that debris broke away and smashed against Columbia's left wing; documents show that NASA concluded that damage from such breakaway foam did not threaten shuttle safety and determined that fuel tank attached to previous shuttle, Endeavour, was 'safe to fly with no new concerns and no added risk' (M)

headline.main: Foam Risk Was Studied Before Fatal Flight

results.snippet: In preparing for the shuttle mission immediately before the fatal Columbia flight, NASA flagged as a major concern a loss of foam in the same area on fuel tanks where investigators now theorize that debris broke away and smashed against the...
results.lead_paragraph: In preparing for the shuttle mission immediately before the fatal Columbia flight, NASA flagged as a major concern a loss of foam in the same area on fuel tanks where investigators now theorize that debris broke away and smashed against the Columbia's left wing. The space agency concluded that damage from such breakaway foam did not threaten shuttle safety and determined that the fuel tank attached to the previous shuttle, the Endeavour, was ''safe to fly with no new concerns and no added risk,'' say documents that NASA released on Thursday.

results.abstract: Ken Kalfus's first novel The Commissariat of Enlightenment is fictional story about Vladimir Lenin, Joseph Stalin and Leo Tolstoy, and addresses issues of propaganda, spectacle and media; photo (M)

headline.main: It Started With a Vision of Tolstoy's Death, Then Segued Into a First Novel

results.snippet: After Leo Tolstoy fled from his family in 1910, he lay dying in a railway station in the small provincial town of Astapovo. Reporters, photographers and a Pathé newsreel team swarmed to the place and breathlessly awaited news, hoping to record the...
results.lead_paragraph: After Leo Tolstoy fled from his family in 1910, he lay dying in a railway station in the small provincial town of Astapovo. Reporters, photographers and a Pathé newsreel team swarmed to the place and breathlessly awaited news, hoping to record the writer's last words. On the sidelines were Stalin and Lenin. All this is true, including the film crew -- except for Stalin and Lenin, who were in Astapovo only in Ken Kalfus's first novel, ''The Commissariat of Enlightenment.''

results.snippet: Best Bet      The latest conference at Hofstra University takes up the past, present and future of ''The Broadway Musical, 1920-2020.'' The four-day eventopens with a ''Welcome to the Cabaret'' salute to Dorothy Fields at 8 p.m. on Wednesday; it...
results.lead_paragraph: Best Bet The latest conference at Hofstra University takes up the past, present and future of ''The Broadway Musical, 1920-2020.'' The four-day eventopens with a ''Welcome to the Cabaret'' salute to Dorothy Fields at 8 p.m. on Wednesday; it continues through Sunday with scholarly papers and panels, devoted to topics like ''Directors and Choreographers,'' ''Ziegfeld,'' ''The Business of Broadway,'' ''The Making of a Musical'' and ''The Musical and the Inner City.'' Next Sunday will also feature a performance of a revised version of ''What Makes Sammy Run?'' at which Budd Schulberg, who wrote the book, and Ervin Drake, its lyricist, will appear to discuss their work.

results.snippet: SURE, ''You had me at hello'' is a tired joke now, but the first time we heard it -- along with ''Show me the money'' and ''You complete me'' -- in Cameron Crowe's charming JERRY MAGUIRE (1996), it was touching. Tom Cruise stars as Jerry, a...
results.lead_paragraph: SURE, ''You had me at hello'' is a tired joke now, but the first time we heard it -- along with ''Show me the money'' and ''You complete me'' -- in Cameron Crowe's charming JERRY MAGUIRE (1996), it was touching. Tom Cruise stars as Jerry, a high-powered sports agent who loses his job for having a brief attack of principle. Renée Zellweger is Dorothy, the adoring agency employee who joins him in his new business. Cuba Gooding Jr., who won the best supporting actor Oscar, is their only client, a football player in a slump. Dorothy's sister (Bonnie Hunt) has the film's real best line. Waiting to meet Dorothy's date, Jerry, she says, ''I just hope he's not good-looking'' -- Monday at 10:30 p.m. and Saturday at 6:30 p.m. on Showtime. Vincent Freeman wants to be an astronaut. But in Andrew Niccol's futuristic GATTACA (1997), only perfect human specimens are allowed to go into space, and Vincent (Ethan Hawke) was conceived the old-fashioned way, not genetically engineered like everybody else. So he fakes an identity, stealing it from Jerome Morrow (Jude Law), a star swimmer until an accident paralyzed him. One day, Vincent leaves one of his own eyelashes lying around in the wrong place, its DNA establishes that he's not ''valid,'' and we have ourselves a crime thriller. Uma Thurman is Vincent's puzzled but good-hearted love interest -- Sunday at 9 a.m. on Sci Fi.

results.abstract: UCLA Hammer Museum presents exhibition of Auditorium Piece, work by Japanese-born, London-based artist Tomoko Takahashi; interview; photo (S)

headline.main: Just a Junk Pile? Of Course Not

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: HAMMER, ARMAND, MUSEUM OF ART AND CULTURAL CENTER

results.snippet: NEARLY hidden within the recesses of the Hammer Museum here at the University of California is the concrete and cinder-block shell of an amphitheater that will one day be a plush screening room. For now, however, it is home to a breathtaking pile of...
results.lead_paragraph: NEARLY hidden within the recesses of the Hammer Museum here at the University of California is the concrete and cinder-block shell of an amphitheater that will one day be a plush screening room. For now, however, it is home to a breathtaking pile of junk. Measuring 50 by 80 feet and sloping to a height of almost 30 feet, the pile first appears to be the aftermath of an earthquake. Walk along the platform overlooking the auditorium and what comes into view, bit by bit, are found objects picked up from Los Angeles curb sides, prop houses and the nearby desert: the cockpit of an airplane, an inch-high plastic astronaut, a lopsided fireplace, a cedar-sided Jacuzzi, an upright piano, a slumping picket fence. Light bulbs blink, fans turn and television screens flicker while rivers of electrical wire zigzag about like arteries in search of a heart. An incongruous neo-Classical column lying on its side bisects the space.

results.abstract: NASA deputy associate administrator Maj Gen Michael C Kostelnik says three other shuttles in space shuttle fleet may be needed until 2020, despite breakup of Columbia in earth's atmosphere on February 11 killing all seven astronauts on board; says agency could cut risks in later years, when shuttles will be approaching 40 years old, by flying with fewer astronauts or none at all if planned orbital space plane is ready; says shuttle could become cargo vehicle if job of ferrying astronauts is turned over to orbital space plane, vehicle NASA hopes to have in service by 2012, although agency may set earlier goal; photos (M)

headline.main: Future Shuttles May Carry Fewer Astronauts or None at All, NASA Official Says

results.snippet: Despite the breakup of the shuttle Columbia, the three other ships in the fleet may be needed until 2020, a top NASA official said today.     He added that NASA could cut the risks in later years, when the shuttles will be approaching 40 years old,...
results.lead_paragraph: Despite the breakup of the shuttle Columbia, the three other ships in the fleet may be needed until 2020, a top NASA official said today. He added that NASA could cut the risks in later years, when the shuttles will be approaching 40 years old, by flying with fewer astronauts or none at all if a planned orbital space plane is ready.

results.abstract: NASA Aerospace Safety Advistory Panel says NASA should seriously study crew escape systems for space shuttle and deploy them or re-examine high risk of human space flight; repeats earlier calls to study methods to allow crew to escape crippled shuttle at any point; Sean O'Keefe, NASA administrator, says that agency is working to make space flight safer but that only way to eliminate risk entirely is to stop flying (M)

headline.main: Safety Panel Urges NASA To Examine Shuttle Escape

results.snippet: NASA safety advisers said today that the agency should seriously study crew escape systems for the space shuttle and deploy them or re-examine the high risk of human space flight.    In releasing its annual report to the space agency, the experts,...
results.lead_paragraph: NASA safety advisers said today that the agency should seriously study crew escape systems for the space shuttle and deploy them or re-examine the high risk of human space flight. In releasing its annual report to the space agency, the experts, the NASA Aerospace Safety Advisory Panel, repeated earlier calls to study methods to allow a crew to escape a crippled shuttle at any point.

results.abstract: Pieces of space shuttle Columbia continue to be delivered to Kennedy Space Center, where technicians are reconstructing craft's wings from collected debris; hardly anything from left wing has been found, yet that void could provide clues; investigators say much more heat entered left side than right, apparently burning away structure before it could fall to Earth; photo; in separate development from Soyuz project, one American and one Russian astronaut headed for International Space Station will take off on Apr 26 in first piloted craft to be launched since Columbia disaster (M)

headline.main: Missing Pieces of Columbia's Left Wing May Provide Clues

results.snippet: On the floor of a 40,000-square-foot hangar here, technicians have marked three outlines of the shuttle Columbia's wings to lay down wreckage from the bottom, the middle and the top of the wings.    Although it looks systematic, there is a problem....
results.lead_paragraph: On the floor of a 40,000-square-foot hangar here, technicians have marked three outlines of the shuttle Columbia's wings to lay down wreckage from the bottom, the middle and the top of the wings. Although it looks systematic, there is a problem. Hardly anything from the left wing has been found. Yet that void may yield clues.
